titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. V:15. Change of weather in the morning— Chill North-east wind— Bath with John at the wharf, and swam near half an hour. Shaw went to Boston in the Stage— I wrote a few lines of poetry in the Album of my niece Elizabeth Coombs Adams at her request. I spent some time in examining the old Volume of Church Records, and traced my Ancestors back to the baptism of my Grandfather John, son of Joseph Adams in 1691— He was the son of another Joseph who died in 1694. at the age of 68 years in 1694. he must have been born therefore in England in 1626. He was one of the seven Sons of Henry Adams the first emigrant of the family, and who was one of the first settlers of the town of Braintree— Dr Holbrook came over this morning to see my Coachman Joseph Abbot, who was seized yesterday with a bilious fever— Mrs Hall, formerly Elizabeth Smith came out to dine at my fathers— Shaw sent us out from Boston a Man to drive our Carriage— Dined with Mrs Adams, and George at Governor Eustis’s at Roxbury— It was rather a tumultuary party— Coll. Haynes, a Senator elect from South-Carolina, and W. S. Archer, member of the House of Representatives from Virginia were of the Company— Also Mr John Brazier, and Rufus G. Amory— About the middle of the dinner
the Antient and Honourable Artillery came out from Boston, and paraded in the Governor’s yard in front of his House. He reviewed them, and they gave him a Salute— The Officers were invited into the house; and refreshments were served to the company in a marquee in the yard. In the Evening we came in to Boston, and took lodgings at the Exchange Coffee-House, kept by Major Hamilton one of the Officers of the same antient and honourable Artillery Company— Mr Thomas B. Johnson, my wife’s brother also lodges at the same house. And also W. S. Shaw— Mr Joseph Hall the Sheriff called in the Evening to see us.

2. V:30. From seven O’Clock this Morning till Noon, there was a continual succession of visitors. At that time I rode out with Dr Parkman to Mr John Prince’s at Brookline, to see several remarkable imported Bulls. As we were riding Parkman told me many circumstances which occurred in the last year of the life of the late Mayor of Boston, John Phillips—one of the intimate friends of my early life; but whom for the last thirty years I had seldom seen. He also mentioned to me anecdotes concerning Washington Irving, and Mr Marryat the Member of Parliament and his family— Dined with Mrs Adams, and her brother T. B. Johnson at Mr Harrison G. Otis’s— Mrs Otis was absent, with her Daughter Mrs Lyman at Watertown, who is alarmingly ill, in a threatened consumption— Miss Sophia Otis did the honours in the place of her mother— The company was about twenty— Splendid as usual— We went successively to two Evening party’s— First at Mrs J. Joy’s; and next at Mr Thomas L. Winthrop’s. The latter a Ball, from which we returned to our lodgings about Midnight.

3. VI. I went with W. S. Shaw this morning to the Athenaeum at the House given by the late Mr James Perkins in Pearl Street— Returned to Breakfast— Had a succession of Visitors from eight, till Noon— I then called with Mr Cruft, upon Stewart the Painter, and engaged him to go out to Quincy, and there paint a Portrait of my father— More than twenty years have passed since he painted the former portrait; and time has wrought so much of change on his countenance that I wish to possess a likeness of him as he now is— Stewart started some objections, of trivial difficulties— The want of an Easel, of a room properly adapted to the light; but finally promised that he would go, and take with him his best brush, to paint a picture of Affection, and of curiosity for future times— I then called at Mr James H. Foster’s, and at John Brazier’s. He told me that the Antient and Honourable had been affronted at their reception by the Governor on Monday—Because there had been only a dessert of fruit and liquor for them; while their Officers had been invited into the House— Dined with Mrs. Adams and George at Mr Hall the Sheriffs—with a company of about twenty— Spent the Evening, with George at Degrand’s lodgings, where a company of nearly two hundred Republicans assembled, and all of whom he introduced to me— I had before been acquainted only with a small number of them— We retired between ten and eleven. My Sons John and Charles came in from Quincy.

4. VI. A succession of visitors occupies every morning almost from the moment of my rising till Noon when I seize the first vacant moment to go out— This morning I had calls from B. O. Tyler of Washington City, and from Isaac Munroe Editor of the Baltimore Patriot, who is here on a visit— They and Degrand talk much upon the subject of the next Presidential Election; a topic upon which I would gladly neither speak nor hear a word
till it shall be over. I went with Mr Cruft to Mrs Lecane’s—keeper of a boarding house in his neighbourhood; to enquire if my Son George can have lodgings there, and on what terms. Her house is now full, but she said there might be a vacancy, by the beginning of the next Month. Stopp’d also at Mr Crufts and saw his wife, who is confined to her chamber and his son Edward, a boy of ten or eleven years of age, afflicted with a disease which threatens to cripple him for life— I paid a visit also to judge Dawes, a man who has been useful, and amiable in his day; but whose declining years are not happy— He has been oppressed in his circumstances by a numerous family, and now his wife, always an excellent and lovely woman has so lost her hearing that they can converse together only by gestures or by writing— He told me that since I left Washington, judge Cranch had been taken ill with a fever. That Mr and Mrs Elliot were convalescent, but would probably lose one of their children— I returned the visit of Mr Archer, who lodges also at the Exchange Coffee-House— Went out with Degrand, and dined at General H. A. S. Dearborn’s at Brinley Place, Roxbury. There was a company of about 30. men—among whom Coll. Hayne’s the Senator, and Mr Archer—Crowninshield, Silsbee, and Sprague of Salem— There was at table a Conversation chiefly between Coll. Haynes and George Blake, upon a decision of Judge Johnson of the U.S. Supreme Court, pronouncing an Act of the Legislature of South-Carolina unconstitutional, in which Haynes discovered so much excitement and temper, that it became painful, and necessary to change the topic— It was the act prohibiting free persons of Colour from coming or being brought into the State as sailors, upon penalties among which are their being sold as Slaves— Crowninshield claimed my promise made two years ago that I would dine with him at Salem, and I engaged to go next Wednesday. Mr Silsbee engaged me to go and lodge at his house— I had a conversation in the garden with Mr Sprague— Returned to Boston, and called at Mr Shepherd’s, where Mrs Adams, her brother, and George had dined— Found them just going away; but they went back; and there was music— Mr Shepherd is a widower, with a daughter of about 14—and her governess, a Mademoiselle Barrière, handsome and accomplished— She performed on the Piano, and sung— Shepherd was an acquaintance of Mr Johnson’s at New-Orleans, and has lately removed to Boston.

5. V:45.Thomas Hellen came from Exeter, where he is placed at the Academy; and they have now a short vacation— Had the usual flock of Visitors all the Morning. Went with George to the State-Bank, and made a transfer to him of twenty shares in its Stock. Received also two dividends due to me there. I paid several visits, and among the rest to Coll. Thomas H. Perkins— Call also at the Athenaeum— Dined at Mr William Gray’s; with a Company of twenty men—No Lady, except Mrs Gray— President Kirkland was of the Company, and at table I enquired of him what prospect they had of erecting their astronomical Observatory at the University— He said there had been done nothing concerning it lately— I expressed a strong wish that they would resume the purpose and accomplish it. Urging the essential usefulness of such an Establishment— The honour of the University; the credit of the Country— The advancement of Science— President Kirkland, turning to Mr Gray, said he hoped, there would be the encouragement, of those who possessed the means, of promoting this object; and Mr Gray, in general terms expressed a willingness to give his assistance to it— From Mr Gray’s we went out to a splendid Ball, given by Miss Lyman at Waltham— Miss Lyman is the beauty of this region, and her father one of the wealthiest men of Massachusetts or of the Union. It is said he has spent 150000 dollars upon this Country Seat, which is a little Palace— The party was very numerous; the dancing elegant; the Music charming, the supper sumptuous— All Magnificent and more princely than Republican— The dancers were all of the next Generation to mine— Children of my contemporaries and Juniors. Sons and daughters of those with whom I had often danced, when they were the Sparklers of the Ball room. This metamorphosis
from a blooming Belle into a Mama, seems thus upon a return home after many years of absence, as if it had been the effect of one day— It was near one in the Morning when we got back to our Lodgings at Boston.

6. VI. I found time this morning to answer Letters received from General William Hull, of Watertown, Governor Wolcott of Connecticut and Mr Archibald Gracie of New-York. Hull has requested an interview with me, for which I have appointed next Tuesday, or Wednesday. The life we are leading is too fatiguing for Mrs Adams who is quite unwell. We nevertheless dined with her brother, at Mr James Lloyd, and had a numerous party of Ladies and Gentlemen— In the Evening we came out to my father’s at Quincy, where we found Thomas J. Hellen, my Sons and W. S. Shaw.

7. VI. Heard Mr Whitney this Morning from John 3.8. “The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh, and whither it goeth: so is every one that is born of the Spirit.” In the afternoon we went to the Episcopal Church; and heard Mr Cutler; a young Clergyman, recently settled there— He is the Son of Benjamin Clark Cutler, now deceased; once Sheriff of the County of Norfolk; and at whose house I slept on the 30th. of March 1803. at Roxbury— His widow now resides here with her Son, and she has a daughter married to a Mr M’Allister of Savannah, Georgia, but now also here on a visit— The Episcopal Church here has not had a settled Minister here, since our revolutionary War till within these two years when they settled this Mr Cutler— He read the service very well, and preached a good Sermon, but forgot to name his text which was from the 63d. Chapter of Isaiah— After Church I called and visited at Mr Marston’s, and at Mr G. W. Apthorp’s— Walked home with my Sons John and Charles— We were overtaken by a heavy shower of rain, and drenched through. I continue my examination of the little volume of Braintree Church Records, lent me by Mr Whitney. I find in it several interesting facts respecting my ancestors, to which I obtain further elucidations by consulting my fathers Memory— But there is a large chasm in the evidence prior to the year 1672—at which period this book begins— It has occurred to me that this may be supplied by the Town Records of the Town of Braintree.

8. V:45. Came into Boston, again, with Mrs Adams. We called on our way, at Mr Quincy’s, and saw his wife and daughters. I spoke to them of the Church and Town Records, and enquired if they had any notices of the Quincy family; from the time of the settlement of Braintree. I found they had several, to which I shall refer hereafter— We called also at Governor Eustis’s; but he was gone in to Boston, and I found his card at our lodgings. We met Mr and Mrs Richard Sullivan, calling as we arrived— A number of other visitors followed— I went with W. S. Shaw to Stewart’s, and asked him to go out to my father’s to-morrow Morning to paint his Portrait; at which time he had agreed to sit— Stewart now started so many difficulties, that Shaw was convinced he had determined not to go— Shaw called on him however again in the Evening, and he agreed to go with him in our Carriage to-morrow Morning. I called at Isaac P. Davis’s, but found him with his family at dinner. Dined with Mrs Adams and George at Mrs Humphreys’s — The party was small— The Roman Catholic Bishop Cheverus was there. Going immediately, and as he says against his will to France under a peremptory order from the King, to be Bishop of Montauban— Mr Andrew Ritchie was also of the party—Lately returned from France. And H. G. Otis, with whom I had after dinner a Conversation respecting the Correspondence about to be published— Otis also mentioned to me some Letters which my father has lately written to him. Returned late to our lodgings.

9. VI.W. S. Shaw went with Mr Stewart this Morning out to Quincy, and my father sat for his picture— I had a succession of Visitors all the morning— Among the rest Jacob Eustis, the Governor’s brother— Henry Gray, and General Hull who came by appointment. Eustis is as he always was an
eternal talker of Nothings. From his half-ideas, a tolerable inference can be drawn of his brother’s whole ones— Henry Gray came respecting a Vessel and Cargo, his and his father’s taken by a piratical privateer from Porto-Rico— General Hull came to urge a claim for Salary as Governor of the Territory of Michigan in 1812. additional to the pay of a Major General, which he received at the same time. He urged various reasons for its payment, of which he is no doubt in great want— I told him I would again represent his claim to the President upon my return to the City of Washington. He asked me also upon what grounds the American Plenipotentiaries at Ghent had declared that the American Government had disapproved his proclamation issued upon his entering Canada— I said it was from the assurance of Mr Gallatin that the fact was within his personal knowledge— He said his Proclamation never had been disapproved— He has now the appearance of an unhappy man as he is. Dined with Mrs Adams and George at Mr Pickman’s; with a family party— Coll. Pickman of Salem was there—Mrs Cutts of Portsmouth, and Mr Cruft. I called this morning at Dr Welsh’s, and again in the Evening with Mrs Adams— We only saw Mrs Welsh— The Doctor being at the Island— This Morning a pamphlet was published, purporting to be by Ephraim May Cunningham, Son of the late William Cunningham of Fitchburg— It is a correspondence between my father and William Cunningham, partly written in 1804. and partly in 1808. 9 and 10.— It contains a number of Letters written at those respective times by my father with his characteristic frankness, and under the excitement of different feelings at the different periods— The malignity of the publication consists in its being now made for the purpose of injuring me, by exciting personal enmities against me among leading men of both parties, and their families and friends— There is an introduction of venomous bitterness, well written and attributed to the pen of Jonathan Russell; who together with Mr Crawford has the credit of contributing to bring it forth. How far this is true I have not evidence sufficient clearly to ascertain— On or About the 8th. of May last, William Cunningham shot himself— In June Mr Bailey received a Letter from Dr Bates intimating that a Correspondence was to be published which was to blast my reputation and my father’s— In August Dr Waterhouse wrote me that Governor Eustis was making efforts well meant no doubt, but if so, very injudicious, to suppress the publication— The newspapers of Mr Crawford’s Scapegibbets began to let out the secret of the Mine that was to blow me up. And since I have been here the publication has been letting out whiffs of smoke from day to day, till the great explosion of this Morning— And blessed be God, here I am, sound wind and limb; neither better nor worse for the Cunningham Correspondence.

10. VI. I have intended to go down to Portland to confer with Governor Parris of the State of Maine upon the question of our North-eastern boundary with the British dominions; and this morning I went with Mr Cruft, and looked at the Steam-boat which is to go there weekly— I found the boat small and not promising to be very comfortable. Among the numerous visitors of this day was Mr Insinger of Antwerp, Mr Parish of the British Legation, and Mr And Mrs Seaton of the City of Washington— I made also several visits and among them to Mr Quincy the Mayor— Who was not at home— I visited also the Mummy, sent to this Country by Mr Van Lennep, and read Dr Warren’s description of it, with Campbell’s lines upon Belzoni’s Mummy. Dined at George Blake’s— The Governor and Mrs Eustis there. Mr and Mrs Morton, and perhaps twenty others. The Governor proposed to go with me to Portland, but could not go in the Steam-boat— Perhaps not in the Stage— He talked whimsically to Mrs Adams at the table— After dinner I called upon Judge Davis, and went with him to Mr Phillips’s; the son of the late Lieutenant Governor, to our old Wednesday Evening Club— Talk about an Observatory. Savage at Phillips’s, and now one of the Club— Quincy the Mayor also there.

11. VI.Degrand was here this morning and calls every morning— Henry Gray came, with papers concerning the capture of his Vessel the Otter; carried into the Island of Porto-Rico. He cannot conceive that the Government should be destitute of authority to recapture his vessel by force; or issue reprizals to indemnify him— I went out with Mr and Mrs Seaton, and my Son George, to my Father’s at Quincy; the Boston Fusileer Company who have been these two days encamped on the Hill opposite to his House went this day to give him at Noon a marching and firing salute. They had invited me to their encampment this afternoon, which invitation I was obliged to decline— But I went to meet them at my fathers— There was a cold Collation, and the whole company shook hands with him, and with me. Stewart the Painter was there— My father had been sitting to him; and he told me that he would make a picture of it that should be admired as long as the materials would hold together— Return’d to Boston, by the road over Milton Hill. Dined with Mrs Adams; her brother and George, at Mr James T. Austin’s, with a party of Ladies and Gentlemen— The Governor and Mrs Eustis there. Mrs Gerry—Blake’s, Dearborn’s, Hall’s &c. Evening with a numerous party at Mrs S. A. Otis’s— My Sons John and Charles came in to Town, for a projected party to Nahant to-morrow.

12. VI. Went with our party to Nahant. I had intended to go myself in the Steam-boat which usually goes at eight in the Morning; but the weather was so foggy, that they dared not venture out in her— After waiting an hour at the Athenaeum in vain for the fog to clear away, I returned to our lodgings, and went in a Hack, with Mr and Mrs Seaton, and my Son George— Mrs Adams and my Sons John and Charles— Mr Shepherd, with his daughter and her governess: Mrs Ellery widow of Abraham R. Ellery, and her three daughters, John and Harriet Welsh, constituted the company— The Hotel at Nahant built by Coll. T. H. Perkins, is kept by Captain Magee, an old East-India Captain— We met there Mr W. Tudor, and his Mother— Mr and Mrs Hubbard: Mr and Mrs Dowse and Mrs Shaw—and Mrs John Gore— But the Season is over and the place is nearly deserted—. We fished for perch about half an hour with poor success— There was a thick fog the whole time we were there— We dined at two— And after a walk to the rocks, left the Hotel about four and returned to the City— As the Sun went down, and we were winding over the beach the fog cleared away perfectly fair— It was dark when we got back, and we immediately went to a crowded Ball at Mrs Elwyn’s. I had there some conversation with Isaac P. Davis, on the subject of erecting an Astronomical Observatory— Home about Midnight.

13. VI. I called on Francis C. Gray at his Office, to converse with him on the project of an Observatory connected with a professorship of Astronomy at Cambridge— I asked him to bespeak the assistance of his father which he promised me he would— I called at Sheriff Hall’s, and with him on President Kirkland at Cambridge— He went with us to Mr Nathaniel Amory’s at Watertown, where we dined— He has there an elegant Country-Seat, with spacious gardens— The company as usual about twenty men— I had some Conversation before dinner with Coll. T. H. Perkins upon this Observatory and Professorship, towards which he is well disposed. The subject was also mentioned at table to Mr James Lloyd who did not so well receive it. He thought there were so many things for which subscriptions were called, and so there are. The calls for charitable and benevolent contribution, are inexhaustible— Why should not their supply be so to— In the Evening we took President Kirkland home; and I went with Sheriff Hall to his door— Then returned to lodge at our Exchange Coffee-House chambers— Mrs Adams and all my Sons, were gone out to my fathers at Quincy— Mr T. B. Johnson was doubting whether he would go out with me to-morrow Morning or not.

14. VI.Mr T. B. Johnson did not make his appearance this morning. I took a Horse and Chaise, and came out to my fathers at Quincy— Stopped at Governor Eustis’s at Roxbury, on my way; to enquire if he would go with me to Portland— My plan was to go next Wednesday to Salem— Thursday and Friday to Princeton; return thence the ensuing Monday, and the next day to proceed to Portland— I found the Governor doubtful whether he could go— Determined that he would not go in the Steam-Boat. Sure that he could not stop at all at Portsmouth, and having some other humours, not very accommodating for a fellow traveller— He will have a Note left to-morrow week at my lodgings to let me know whether he will go with me— He spoke of the Cunningham Correspondence, and said he knew the hand of every line in the introduction as well as if he had been present at its being penned— (Meaning by Jonathan Russell.) He talks strangely but he means me to think him my friend— I took back the Instruction to R. Rush, and the Maps that I had left with him— It was near Noon when I reached my father’s House— But in the afternoon I heard Mr Richmond, from Galatians 2.17. “But if, while we seek to be justified by Christ, we ourselves also are found sinners, is therefore Christ the Minister of Sin? God forbid.”— Mr Richmond is a very cold preacher— Charles Foster came out from Boston this afternoon and returned; and Mr Marston was here in the Evening.

15. VI. I had engagements again this week in Boston; but the Letters that I receive almost every day from Washington, where Mr Brent, Mr Bailey, and Mr Baker of the Department of State are all confined with fevers, warn me that I must return to my stated duties there early in the next Month. If I go to Princeton and to Portland, so much of the remnant of my Time will be absorbed that I shall scarcely have a day left to pass with my father. I incline to give up one or both of my Journies— I wrote this morning a Letter to Judge Davis upon the subject of the Observatory— Had a Conversation with my father upon the subject of James A. Bayard; who my father says, solicited of him the Mission to France in 1801. Though he knew that on the accession of Mr Jefferson his appointment would be vacated, and declined the appointment; when made, on that ground.— Dined with my wife and my Son George at Mr Webster’s at Dorchester. Mr John Welles and his wife were there— And Mr Parish, of the British Legation at Washington. Mr Webster gave me a Letter from Mr Duer of Albany, whom I had seen at my father’s house on my arrival here; and who had then invited me to take Albany on my way back. He now advises that I should not come; from an apprehension that it might be attributed to an electioneering movement— I had no thoughts of returning through Albany— We came in to Boston after dinner, and spent the Evening with a party, at my old Classmate Jonathan Amory’s— The company was numerous; and Mrs Elwyn, told me it was many years since she had first seen me— I was making an awkward apology for not remembering it, when she said she had seen me, but I had not seen her. It was from a window in Market Street Philadelphia in January 1791. She had seen me descend from a Carriage, with my brother Charles, whom she knew, to pay a morning visit to Mr Jefferson, then Secretary of State; who lodged at a house directly opposite that in which she then a girl, lived with her father, a Senator from New-Hampshire— I well recollect having at that time paid that visit to Mr Jefferson— But this anecdote now reminded me in a striking manner, how many people there are observing us every hour of our lives, when we are in no wise conscious of it— We returned at the close of the Evening to our lodgings.

16. VI. Went with all my family, upon a party down the harbour, in the Revenue Cutter, Captain Trevett— Mr Cruft, Mr William Sturges; Mr and Mrs Seaton, and Harriet Welsh were of the party— We embarked in boats from the bottom of the Long Wharf about nine in the morning. Fine Weather and Calm. A light breeze soon came up, and we went out five or six miles below the Light-House— We fished two or three hours—caught a number of mackerel— Several Haddock, a few Cod; and many Hake, a fish
with which I had not before been acquainted— We returned so as to land just at the dusk of the Evening upon the Long Wharf— And immediately afterwards to a splendid Ball at Mr David Sears’s— His House is Magnificent, and almost princely— He spoke to me of the Observatory, and Professorship of Astronomy; as of an object to the accomplishment of which he would readily give assistance— We returned to the Exchange about Midnight.

17. VI: I had written last week to Mr W. N. Boylston, that I would this week visit him at Princeton; and that he might expect us on Friday; but I have so few days left to pass with my father, and shall so soon be obliged to return to Washington, that I concluded not to go. Mr J. B. Davis was here this morning: going to-morrow for Princeton— I requested him to call on Mr Boylston and inform him of my disappointment, in being compelled to postpone my visit to him— We determined however finally that Mrs Adams and Charles should go to-morrow, and return at the beginning of the next week— Degrand, Judge Davis, Sheriff Hall, and T. Fuller called on me this morning. Fuller appears to be much dissatisfied with the election of Mr Bailey, for Norfolk District— I took George with me in a Chaise to Salem— Leaving the Horse and Chaise at the Essex Coffee-House, we went immediately to Mr N. Silsbee’s; and thence to Mr B. W. Crowninshield’s, where we dined with a company of about 25 men— Mrs Crowninshield at table— We then visited judge Story; afterwards passed the Evening at Mr Treadwell’s, with a numerous company of Republicans, and then came to spend the Night at Mr Silsbee’s— Mrs Silsbee is confined by severe illness to her chamber.

18. VI. Lines on Memory. Begun and abandoned— Captain Bainbridge and General Dearborn breakfasted with us at Mr Silsbee’s— Afterwards Mr Sprague, judge Story and his brother came in— Visited with them the Salem Museum; where I met a number of other persons who were introduced to me— Then we returned to the Essex Coffee House— And came back to Boston, through Cambridge— We stop’d at Dr. Waterhouse’s. And George took from the Chamber in the College which has been John’s and Charles’s some of his books— We got to our lodgings at the Exchange Coffee-House about four in the Afternoon— But twice in this excursion to Salem, have we narrowly escaped getting our necks broken— Once yesterday, going into Salem, by the stumbling of the horse, and once this day in a narrow lane of Boston, by locking one of our wheels into that of a Cart— We found that Mrs Adams and Charles had gone off this morning in a horse and Chaise to Princeton. We dined at Boston, and came out after dinner to my father’s House at Quincy— In the Evening I attended a large tea-party at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s.

19. VI. Morning ride with my father to Bent’s point— We stop’d at the House of Jedediah Adams, who at my father’s request lent me the old official copy of the Will of my father’s great-Grandfather Joseph Adams Senior, who died in 1694— In the afternoon we rode down to Mr Quincy’s, and saw Mrs Quincy and her Daughters— The eldest Susan lent me, several papers relating to the Quincy family; among them an authenticated copy of the Will of the secondEdmund Quincy, grandfather of my great Grandfather John Quincy—dated in 1697— Also a funeral Sermon upon the thirdEdmund Quincy, preached in 1737. by John Hancock Minister of the Church in Braintree— I read it this Evening to my father, who had never seen it before. This Edmund Quincy had been sent as the Agent of the Province to England; and died in London, of the Small-pox— And the grant from the Town of Boston, of Mount Wollaston, to the first Edmund Quincy, in the year 1633— Mr Henry Gray came out from Boston this afternoon, and brought papers respecting the capture of his Brig Otter, Captain Keating by a Porto-Rico Privateer— He asked me for a Letter to the Governor of Porto-Rico, which I promised to send him.

20. VI.My brother went to Medford. I rode this morning with my father to Mr Cotton Tufts’s at Weymouth— They have a Son, and two daughters full grown— We compared recollections of the times that we had met since I left College— It was twice or thrice at most— On returning home I found at my father’s house Mr J. Connell of Philadelphia, who remained and dined with us. He seemed to have come from Philadelphia, to enquire of the state of his claims on Denmark; but I can do nothing concerning them here. He returned to Boston after dinner— I walked with my Son George to Mr Quincy’s where we passed the Evening— Mrs Cutler, with her Son in Law and daughter the M’Allister’s, were all the Company— Shaw came out from Boston this Evening.

21. VI. Heard Mr Brooks of Hingham—this morning from Psalm 73.25. “Whom have I in Heaven but thee? and there is none upon Earth that I desire beside thee.” and in the afternoon from Acts 2.46.47. “And they, continuing daily with one accord in the temple, and breaking bread from house to house, did eat their meat with gladness and singleness of heart— Praising God, and having favour with all the People. And the Lord added to the church daily such as should be saved.” Brooks is a very sensible preacher, of the modern Cambridge School— Mr T. B. Johnson and Mr Newman came out from Boston and dined with us and returned this Evening— After the second Service, I rode with my Son George to Governor Eustis’s at Roxbury— Met Degrand on the way—and Mr Gerry and Mr Waters at the Governor’s— He has concluded that he cannot go with me to Portland as he had proposed—and I gave up the intention of going there, for the present, myself— I have but a few days left before I must return to Washington; and of those days I would devote the most to my father— On returning home I found Mrs Quincy and her Son Josiah, Miss Morton and Mr Marston with Mr Goodwin— Degrand and General Dearborn had been here but were gone— In turning round our small four wheeled one horsed Carriage, I overset in Governor Eustis’s yard— It took little damage and we got it up again easily; with some slight injury to myself, and none to George— My own imprudence was in fault.

22. VI.Shaw returned this Morning to Boston— I rode with my father to Hingham, and visited our relations of the Thaxter family— The first were Celia and Betsey Thaxter; first Cousins of my Mother; old Ladies whom I had scarcely seen for near half a Century, and whom I remember as then young women in the prime of life— Then their brother Quincy Thaxter, and his two daughters Anna and. Thence we called upon Mr Edward Thaxter, son in Law to Mrs Thomas Thaxter— There we met Mr Brooks whom I had heard yesterday at Quincy— We barely called at the house of Mrs Loring, and saw her and her daughter Mrs Whittemore— They made enquiries after my Sons George and John, who had about ten years since been there at School— My own recollections of Hingham revert to my early childhood. We returned home to dinner, and had afternoon visits from Richard Derby and Mr Coffin, who gave me a small volume of Letters from his brother, written in Chili, and recently published— I passed the Evening chiefly alone, in idle meditations.

23. VI. My brother went this Morning to Boston— I rode with my father and my Son John to Randolph; to visit my Cousin John Adams, son of my father’s brother Elihu Adams— He was gone with his wife to Abington to visit his mother and his Sister Mrs Hobart— We saw his Son John a youth of about 17 years of age, and his daughter Mary of about 15— It was about 3 in the afternoon when we reached home, and we found my wife and my Son Charles, returned from their visit to Mr Boyleston at Princeton— I called in the Evening at Mr Whitney’s— Mr Marston was afterwards here— My visit to Randolph went even farther back in my memory even than that to Hingham— I had certainly not before been at Randolph these five and forty years— A second generation is since that time advancing there. The change in their Condition is less than in mine.

24. VI. An equinoctial gale, without rain— My father was yesterday somewhat over fatigued with the length of his ride; which with the tempestuous weather of this day prevented him from riding out. William Tudor came out from Boston; and is preparing to go out upon his appointment as Consul at Lima. I paid afternoon and Evening visits at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and at Captain Beale’s: and I indulged myself great part of the afternoon in reading Mather’s Magnalia. The tale of other Times; and of other Conditions— Will there be any thing better in future Times to tell of this?

25. VI. A Mr Lithgow, formerly of the district of Maine, and now perhaps of Charlestown, came to see me— This afternoon I rode with my father to Weymouth, to see Mr Norton, but he was not at home— On our return we stopp’d at the House of Mr Wales; the town-Clerk of Braintree. I asked to see the Antient records of the town, in his Custody, with the view to ascertain whether they would not contain some documents relating to my ancestors—. I found many; and among them that Henry Adams, who must have been the first of the name who came from England was the first Town Clerk of Braintree, and the first pages of the Record, from 1639 to 1643. are in his hand writing. I found also numerous entries relating to the Quincy Family.

26. VI. The Vacation after Commencement at Cambridge terminates. My Son Charles went, and entered his name, and came back this Evening. I was occupied all the morning in reading papers relating to my private affairs. My brother’s— After dinner I rode with my father and him. First to Braintree— Called to see Mr Storrs the Minister of the Church there, but he was not at home. We then went to Mr Norton’s at Weymouth, and found him at home. Mrs Norton is in ill health. He shewed us an old parchment record of the family of Norton, or Norville, from the time of the Norman Conquest, till the emigration to America—nearly two centuries since. After our return home, Mr Marston came and spent the Evening with us.

27. VI. I went with Mrs Adams to Boston— Visited on our way at Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn’s at Roxbury Saw Mrs Dearborn. Called and left Mrs Adams at Dr Welsh’s where she dined— Stopped at Hamilton’s and then at Mr Cruft’s— He is preparing a settlement of my Affairs in his hands to be delivered over to my Son George. At the Athenaeum, and there met Mr John Pickering, with whom I had conversation, upon his Lexicographical labours. He is publishing a Greek and English Dictionary— Dined with a small party at Mr Isaac P. Davis’s. Judge Davis lent me a book of Zach’s belonging to Mr Bowditch, and containing a good Article upon Astronomical Observatories. Mr B. Joy gave me to take to Quincy a Letter from his brother Michael, concerning Tudor’s life of James Otis, and relating several anecdotes of the pre-revolutionary time, which were of his own knowledge— We returned in the Evening to Quincy, and W. S. Shaw came with us— There was a fire in town as we came out of it. The house in which Marshal Harris lived, part burnt.

28. VI. Heard Mr Dean of Scituate; in the morning from John 8.12. “Then spake Jesus again, unto them, saying; I am the light of the world: he that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.”— An exemplification of the character of Christ and of his religion, as the light of the world— Afternoon from John 5.39. “Search the Scriptures: for in them ye think ye have eternal life: and they are they which testify of me.” The subject was nearly the same as that of the morning. Mr Dean dined with us, as did also Mr Degrand who came out from Boston— After the second Service, I rambled with him over the hills till Evening— Apthorp’s and their Son here.

29. VI.W. S. Shaw returned to Boston— I took my Son Charles in a Chaise to Cambridge. Left him at the room which he occupies alone, at a house called the Lyceum, near the Episcopalian Church— I called successively at President Kirkland’s and Dr Waterhouse’s—both of whom were absent at Boston; and at professor Everett’s and found him at home—much occupied with the cause of the Greeks— I spoke to him of the proposed Observatory. He told me that Mr P. C. Brooks, whose daughter he has recently married, had the intention of bestowing a sum of at least twenty thousand Dollars upon the University, and he asked me to see him before my return to Washington, if I conveniently could, and to urge him to make the appropriation to this purpose; but without saying that he Everett had suggested it to me— I called a second time at President Kirkland’s, but he was at dinner— A third time, and found him— Professors Farrar and Ware came in while I was with him. We conversed on the subject of the proposed Observatory and professorship of Astronomy; but the stimulus of zeal is feeble, and the prospect of success is not flattering. I returned alone to Quincy. There was an Evening party at Mr Marston’s, which I did not attend.

30. VI.Stewart the painter came out from Boston, and my father sat for his Portrait— He took it with him, and I desired he would come and take the last sitting on my father’s birth day; the 30th. of October when he will be 88 years of age. Mrs Cushing of Scituate, widow of the late judge Cushing came with her Nephew named Bowers, and dined here— After dinner Mr Ralph B. Forbes and Mr Amory came on a visit— Forbes told me that his brother’s accident at Buenos-Ayres; a fall from his horse had done him scarcely any injury—which did not agree with his own account of it to me; or with his physician’s certificate. Mr and Mrs Fuller were also here, but I did not see them— And Mr and Mrs M’Allister. This Evening W. S. Shaw came out with a young man from New-York named Joseph Adams; and Mr DeGrand with Mr Joshua Dodge, our Consul at Marseilles— He is going next week to Bristol, Rhode-Island; to be married to a daughter of Mr James D’Wolfe, Senator from that State in Congress; and he invited me to attend the wedding; which will not be in my power— There was a numerous Evening party at Mr G. W. Apthorp’s which I attended, and where there was Music—Piano and singing. My Son George and Mrs Clarke went to Hingham, and returned at Night.

Day. The Month has been devoted to the enjoyment of my friends; and consequently to dissipation—between Boston, Salem and Quincy— Without regular employment—in a perpetual tumult of visits and parties at Boston, and chiefly in devotion to my father here— The waste of time—the want of interesting occupation, and the recourse to industrious trifling have marked almost equally this interval— I receive almost daily packets from Washington where Mr Brent, and several other Clerks in the Department of State have been taken sick, and whither I feel that I must hasten my return— I have been made sensible of the great difficulty that I shall find, when removed from the Public Service, to fix upon an employment which shall fill up my time usefully, and intensely engage my attention— Let me hope that it will not be wanting— My enquiries into the “short and simple annals” of my ancestors here, have been not entirely fruitless— Four Generations of them preceding my father have been here; and yet all of them that remains are the town and parish records of their births, marriages, and deaths. In the space of one full century before the birth of my father, how much of human action, endurance and enjoyment had my forefathers shared since their first settlement in this spot, and of which not a trace remains— Of the 88 years since his birth, how much belongs to the history of the World; and of the time to come, during the remnant of my days, what is to be the use, to any portion of mankind? Lord, teach me so to number them, that I may apply my heart unto Wisdom.—
